page.title: 01LLANSTEFFAN AND LLANYBRI
page.content: Llansteffan and Llanybri occupy the peninsula between the estuaries of the Tywi and Taf rivers in the south-west of the old county of Carmarthenshire, now incorporated in Dyfed. Its highest point is 130 metres above sea level. This is entirely farming country, with no other significant industry. Tourism in a small way also contributes to the local economy. The villages are 8 to 10 miles from the county and market town of Carmarthen. 750 adults are listed on the Electoral Register. Pilgrims in past centuries crossed the Tywi by ferry from Ferryside to Llansteffan, went on over the peninsula, and crossed the Taf to Laugharne, on their way to St David's. This is our first appearance in a Domesday survey. King William the Conqueror's writ did not run here in 1086.
